The Cu/SiO2 catalyst is widely used in the catalytic hydrogenation reactions of numerous CO bonded compounds, due to its economy and efficiency. In this work, it is found that the EDTA introduced after ammonia evaporation could dissolve part of the copper phyllosilicate in the catalysts prepared by the ammonia-evaporation method, which is called the dissolution effect. Further research shows that the dissolution of the copper phyllosilicate will release Cu2+ ions and silica, then the two will take place ion exchange to form CuOSi units that could be reduced to stable Cu2O. To some extent, the formation of new Cu2O prevents the severe decrease of Cu+ caused by the dissolution of the copper phyllosilicate, which even makes E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst have the highest content of Cu+ (69.1 %). Moreover, the Cu2+ species adsorbed in the silica layers would decrease with the introduction of EDTA, which conduces to the formation of more dispersed Cu0 species with smaller particle sizes. In the hydrogenation reaction of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to ethylene glycol (EG), the optimal catalytic performance (99.86 % DMO conversion and 97.58 % EG selectivity) can be obtained over the E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst at 180 °C during the life evaluation of 300 h. This work reports a strategy for improving the performance and stability of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst by realizing the late redistribution of copper species. Graphical abstract The introduction of moderate EDTA twice in the process of preparing Cu/SiO2 catalysts by the ammonia- evaporationmethod reduces the size of Cu0 nanoparticles and realizes the late redistribution of copper species. Image, graphical abstract Keywords EDTA Cu/SiO2 Dimethyl oxalate, Ethylene glycol, Hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethylene glycol (EG) is a common bulk chemical widely used in polyester, antifreeze and other industries [1,2]. Currently, the ethylene oxide method for the petroleum route and the oxalic ester method for the coal route are the two main production technologies of EG [3,4]. The petroleum route is the traditional production technology of EG, but it is extremely vulnerable to the impact of unstable petroleum prices because of the increasing depletion of petroleum resources and the unpredictable international situation, so the oxalic ester method for the coal route was promptly developed and gradually matured in recent years [5]. In this method, the syngas produced by coal is first converted to dimethyl oxalate (DMO), and then DMO is hydrogenated to create EG. Lamentedly, there are still a few technical difficulties in this method, for instance, the stability of DMO hydrogenation catalysts and the purity of the product still need to be further improved. The hydrogenation of DMO is the final stage in the coal-to-EG process, which directly influences the quality of EG [6]. The copper-based catalyst is the best catalyst for DMO hydrogenation to EG due to its advantages of non-toxicity, low cost and high efficiency [1]. The copper-based catalyst has also been a focus of research in the field of catalysis because it also has outstanding catalytic performance in the hydrogenation of numerous CO bond molecules, including CO2, methyl acetate, ethylene carbonate, furfural, glycerol, etc. [2,7,8]. The copper-based catalyst has strong catalytic activity but low stability and inadequate life because of the aggregation and sintering of copper species, which severely restricts its employment in industrial production [4,9]. Therefore, the primary goal of present research on the copper-based catalyst is to increase its stability and lengthen its service life [10]. The ammonia-evaporation method is a common method for preparing Cu/SiO2 catalysts, and the calcined catalysts prepared by this method mainly contain ion-exchanged CuOSi units, copper phyllosilicate and CuO [11]. It is widely believed that the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0 is the key to catalytic hydrogenation for Cu/SiO2 catalysts [4,11–13], and the Cu+mainly derives from CuOSi units and copper phyllosilicate [14–16]. Because of the larger specific surface area, copper phyllosilicate can give a higher copper content for catalysts [17]. Several studies have indicated that a higher copper phyllosilicate proportion is advantageous to improve catalytic performance [11,18]. Ding et al. [14] reported that ion-exchanged CuOSi units are conducive to the generation of Cu2O species, which are more stable than Cu+ OSi units derived from copper phyllosilicate because the Cu+ OSi unit is easily oxidized back to copper phyllosilicate in the hydrogenation reaction. Therefore, the catalyst with more ion-exchanged CuOSi units prepared by the deposition-precipitation method has higher performance than that prepared by the ammonia-evaporation method. It can be inferred that CuOSi units and copper phyllosilicate are two important copper species in Cu/SiO2 catalysts, and the balance between them is critical to the performance of catalysts. According to this viewpoint, the performance and stability of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst may be further improved if the formed copper phyllosilicate is partly converted into CuOSi units in a controlled way during the preparation of catalysts by the ammonia-evaporation method, so as to optimize the ratio of copper phyllosilicate and CuOSi units. It has been reported that EDTA can extract copper metal from copper mines by dissolving chrysocolla, which has the same structure as copper phyllosilicate [19–21]. Herein, EDTA is introduced into the precursor solution after ammonia evaporation (the bivalent copper species has been basically stable), and it is found that the performance of the catalyst is higher than that of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst without EDTA, but inferior to that (0.08E-Cu/SiO2) of the catalyst introduced EDTA before ammonia evaporation (Table S1). Based on our previous work, therefore, EDTA is added to the Cu/SiO2 catalyst both before and after ammonia evaporation, and the resulting catalyst shows a higher catalytic performance. The effect of EDTA before ammonia evaporation has been reported in the previous work [22], so this work focuses on the effect of EDTA after ammonia evaporation on the already stable copper species. The results show that the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation caused the redistribution of stable bivalent copper species, which optimized the ratio of each copper species, and thus improved the performance of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation All catalysts were prepared using the ammonia-evaporation method as previously reported in the literature (Scheme 1 ) [22]. Taking Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 as an example, the detailed preparation steps are as follows: (a) 10.6 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 6.0 g of urea were completely dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water with stirring, subsequently, 24 mL of 25∼28 wt% ammonia aqueous solution and 42.0 g of 20 wt% silica sol were added successively to the mixed solution at room temperature; (b) the mixed solution was sealed at 80 °C for 1 h and then opened to allow the evaporation of ammonia until the pH reached 6∼7; (c) EDTA (nEDTA/nCu = 0.08) was introduced into the mixed solution after ammonia evaporation, then it needed to be stirred for another 2 h before suction filtration and washing with deionized water at the same time, the cake was dried at 120 °C for 12 h before being calcined at 450 °C for 5 h. This catalyst was named Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2. E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts were prepared based on the 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (x = nEDTA/nCu) [22]. That was, EDTA (nEDTA/nCu = 0.08) was introduced together with the copper source before ammonia evaporation, and then different amounts of EDTA (nEDTA/nCu = x) were introduced again after ammonia evaporation, and the mixed solution should be stirred for another 2 h after EDTA was introduced a second time. The subsequent procedures were the same as that of the Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst, in the end, the obtained catalysts were named E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts (x represented the molar ratio of the second introduced EDTA to copper). 2.2 Dissolution experiment of copper phyllosilicate 2.2.1 Dissolution of copper phyllosilicate in EDTA solution The calcined Cu/SiO2 catalyst of 2.5 g was immersed in 200 mL of EDTA solution with different mass concentrations. The suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h before suction filtration, and the filter cake was dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The resultant samples were given the designation “y-EDTA”, where y (g/L) represented the mass concentration of EDTA. y = 0 indicated that no EDTA was added, this sample served as a blank control. The relative content of copper phyllosilicate in the samples was measured by the value of I673/I800 in the Fourier transform infrared spectra. The pore size distributions of 1-EDTA and 5-EDTA samples were characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption experiments. 2.2.2 Dissolution of copper phyllosilicate in EDTA4Na solution The calcined 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst of 3.0 g was immersed in 200 mL of EDTA solution and EDTA4Na solution (nEDTA = nEDTA4Na). The suspension was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h before suction filtration, and the filter cake was dried at 120 °C for 12 h. The resultant samples were named as “EDTA” or “EDTA4Na”, respectively. The sample immersed in deionized water served as a blank control, which was marked as “H-0.08E-Cu/SiO2”. The relative content of copper phyllosilicate in the samples was measured by the value of I673/I800 in the Fourier transform infrared spectra. 2.3 Catalysts characterization The Cu loadings in catalysts were determined by an inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) produced by HORIBA Jobin Yvon. The C element loadings in the catalysts were measured by an element analyzer (EA) manufactured by Elementar, whose model was Vario EL-Cube. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of catalysts were measured at −196 °C using ASAP 2020 rapid specific surface area and aperture analyzer produced by Micrometrics. The BET equation was used to calculate the specific surface area (SBET) of catalysts. Except for the pore volume (Vp) calculated by the single-point method, the mean pore diameter (Dp) and pore diameter distributions were obtained by the BJH method. N2O pulse titration was used to measure the surface area and dispersion of active copper in catalysts. Firstly, the catalysts were reduced in H2 so that the copper species were reduced to Cu0 and Cu+; then the Cu0 was oxidized to Cu+ by reacting with N2O, and the reaction equation was 2Cu (s) + N2O → N2 + Cu2O (s); finally, reducing Cu+ to Cu0 with H2 pulse. The Cu surface area (SCu) of catalysts was calculated by measuring the amount of hydrogen consumption in the second stage, and the atomic density of copper in catalysts was calculated as 1.46 × 1019 copper atoms per m2. The crystalline state of catalysts was characterized by a Rigaku Miniflex 600 bench powder X-ray diffractometer with Cu target (XRD). The scanning range and speed were 10°∼80°and 2.5°/min, respectively. Bruker Vertex 70 Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was used to characterize the different species in catalysts. The catalysts were made into pieces with KBr in a ratio of 1:100. The wave number range and the spectral resolution were 400∼4000 cm−1 and 4 cm−1. The morphology was observed by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) produced by FEI Company in the United States with an operating voltage of 200 kV. Autochem Ⅱ2920 produced by Micromeritics Corporation of USA was used for the H2-temperature programmed reduction experiment (H2-TPR). The catalysts were pretreated for 2 h in a flowing Ar atmosphere at 120 °C to remove moisture and impurities before testing. After the catalysts were cooled to 50 °C, the Ar flow was replaced with the 10 %H2–90 %Ar flow, then they were heated to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min, meanwhile, the H2 consumption was detected by a TCD detector and an MS signal. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) were determined by the ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (Hν = 1486.6 eV) and multi-channel detector, which was produced by Thermo Fisher, and the binding energy (BE) of Si2p (103.7 eV) was used as the calibration binding energy of XPS. 2.4 Evaluation of catalytic activity The DMO hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a continuous flow gas-solid stainless-steel reactor. Before the hydrogenation reaction, DMO was dissolved in methanol to prepare the raw material liquid with a mass concentration of 0.1 g/mL. The reaction required filling the tube with 1 g of target catalyst (20∼40 meshes), and refractory cellucotton was used to separate the catalyst and quartz sand, which fills the remaining space in the tube to stabilize the H2 flow. Before the reaction, the catalysts were reduced for 5 h in the H2 flow with a flow of 100 mL/min at 300 °C and 2 MPa, and the heating rate was 1 °C/min. The raw material liquid was fed into a carburetor by a high-pressure metering pump at different temperatures, the weight liquid hour space velocity of DMO (WLHSVDMO) was 1.0 h−1 and the molar ratio of H2/DMO was 100, at last, the products were analyzed by gas chromatography with a flame ionization detector. 3 Result 3.1 Structure and physicochemical properties The results of ICP, EA, BET and N2O titration are summarized in Table 1 . According to the results of ICP, the Cu loadings of all catalysts are between 20 % and 22 %, and it exhibits a tendency toward reduction with the increase of EDTA after ammonia evaporation, yet the trend is not severe due to EDTA's restricted introduction. Pursuant to the results of EA, the C loadings of all catalysts are all below the detection limit, which is attributed to the removal of EDTA during the washing process. The results of N2 adsorption-desorption experiment (Fig. S1) reveal that all catalysts have almost identical IV-type isotherms, indicating that they have mesoporous structures [23–25]. The smaller pore size (about 3 nm) is mainly attributed to the copper phyllosilicate layers, while the larger pore size (about 6∼8 nm) is mainly attributed to the SiO2 accumulation [26]. It can be seen from Table 1 and Table S2 that the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation leads to an increase in the average pore size of Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 and E + x-Cu/SiO2 compared with that of Cu/SiO2 and 0.08-Cu/SiO2, respectively. The pore size distribution curves (Fig. S1B) also show that the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation increases the large pore size. The alteration of pore size indicates that there may be the formation of new SiO2 accumulation with the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation. According to the results of N2O titration (Table 1 and Table S2), the SCu of Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst is significantly lower than that of Cu/SiO2 catalyst, and the SCu of E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts is significantly lower than that of 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. It can be inferred that the amount of Cu0 nano-particles (Cu0 NPs) will decrease with the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation. 3.2 Evolution of crystalline phase and morphology The XRD results of calcined catalysts are displayed in Fig. S2. The weak diffraction peaks at 31.5°, 36°, and 57.5° belong to copper phyllosilicate, whereas the wide diffraction peak at around 22° is attributed to amorphous SiO2 [11,27]. The patterns of reduced and used catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 1 , and the diffraction peaks of 37.1° and 43.2° correspond to Cu2O and Cu, respectively [14,28,29]. The Cu peaks of E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst are weaker in both the reduced and used patterns, especially in the used one, besides the Cu peak of used Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst is also weaker than that of Cu/SiO2 catalyst, which is shown in Fig. S3. This indicates that it is beneficial to inhibit the agglomeration of copper species with the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation. In addition, it could be observed by the TEM images (Fig. 2 ) of the used catalysts that the particle sizes of E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 and Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 are reduced to below 2 nm and less than that of 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 catalysts (Fig. S4), respectively, at the same time, the dispersion state of copper species is obviously improved, which is consistent with the results of XRD. This suggests that it is conducive to the formation of smaller and better dispersion copper species with the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation. Only one single reduction peak for all catalysts can be observed in Fig. 3 , which corresponds to the reduction of Cu2+ species (copper phyllosilicate, CuOSi units and copper oxide) [11,18]. The reduction temperatures of E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts are all at about 193.5 °C, which is similar to that of 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst but lower than that of Cu/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S4F). This suggests that it facilitates the formation of smaller copper species with the twice introductions of EDTA. The results of FT-IR are depicted in Fig. 4 , the presence of copper phyllosilicate is demonstrated by both the νSiO asymmetric stretching vibration peak at 1035 cm−1 and the δOH deformation vibration peak at 673 cm−1 [11,13,30]. It has been widely acknowledged that the ratio of the δOH intensity at 673 cm−1 (I673) to the νSiO intensity at 800 cm−1 (I800) could be used to quantify the relative change of copper phyllosilicate [11,14,30]. The results of I673/I800 in Table S3 show that the relative content of copper phyllosilicate decreases obviously with the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation, and that decreases more seriously for the E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts which is introduced EDTA twice. 3.3 Chemical states of surface species The results of XPS analysis performed to determine the chemical state of copper on the catalyst surfaces are displayed in Fig. 5 . All copper species are divalent, which is proved by the photoelectron peaks of Cu 2p3/2 at around 935.8 eV and Cu 2p1/2 at 955.7 eV as well as the satellite vibration peaks at 940∼947 eV and 960∼965 eV [12,31,32]. Copper phyllosilicate and CuOSi units should be responsible for the peak at 935.8 eV, and the CuO is thought to be responsible for the shoulder peak at 933.4 eV [15]. The presence of Cu2O and Cu has been proved by the XRD results of reduced catalysts, therefore the absence of the Cu 2p satellite vibration peak suggests that all copper species undergo reduction transformation from Cu2+ to Cu+ and Cu0. The photoelectron peaks of Cu+ and Cu0 overlap at 933.0 eV, thus the Auger spectrum is utilized to further separate them, whose results are displayed in Fig. 6 and Table 2 , there are the peaks of Cu+ and Cu0 at 913.0 eV and 916.2 eV, respectively [11,33,34]. According to the intensity ratio between Cu+ and (Cu+ + Cu0) by deconvolution of Cu LMM XAES, it is found that the Cu+contents of most catalysts nearly remain unaltered and are quite similar to that of 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2 (Table S4), and only a little rise is seen in the catalyst of E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2. Unexpectedly, the Cu+ content of E + 0.08-Cu/SiO2 decreases significantly, the reasons for which will be explained in the discussion section. 3.4 Solubility of copper phyllosilicate in EDTA and its salts solution It has been reported in industry that the EDTA aqueous solution was used to dissolve copper phyllosilicate [19,20]. In this work, the relationship between the EDTA concentration and the solubility of copper phyllosilicate is further discussed. As shown in Fig. S5A, the relative content of copper phyllosilicate is decreasing dramatically with the increasing concentration of EDTA solution. The peak at 1035 cm−1 totally vanishes as the concentration of EDTA solution reaches 5 g/L, and the value of I673/I800 falls from 0.464 to 0.073, at the same time, the peak of SiOH appears at 970 cm−1 [9,35,36]. According to the results of the dissolution experiment in EDTA solution, it could be inferred that copper phyllosilicate could be completely dissolved in EDTA aqueous solution of 5 g/L, and the dissolution degree of copper phyllosilicate is related to the concentration of EDTA aqueous solution. On the other hand, it can be seen from the pore size distribution curves of 1-EDTA and 5-EDTA in Fig. S6 that the pore size of the samples soaked in EDTA solution increases significantly. Combined with the above characterization, it can be inferred that the dissolution of copper phyllosilicate produces new silica, which can redeposit to form larger mesoporous, being proved by the pore size distribution results of the catalysts (Fig. S1B). It has been proved that EDTA solution can dissolve copper phyllosilicate, but is it only the Y4− ions produced by EDTA ionization play a key role in the dissolution process? To verify this problem, the EDTYA4Na solution was used to dissolve copper phyllosilicate. According to the FT-IR results in Fig. S5B, the I673/I800 in the sample with EDTA4Na declines from 0.458 to 0.314, while the one with EDTA decreases to 0.198. It is easy to conclude that EDTA contributes more to copper phyllosilicate breakdown than Y4− ions during the process. It may be a plausible explanation that Y4− ions hardly directly chelate Cu2+ ions from copper phyllosilicate by reason of the stability of copper phyllosilicate, while EDTA is able to interact with copper phyllosilicate at a certain temperature to destroy the stable structure of copper phyllosilicate, and then Cu2+ ions are gradually released, which could be chelated by Y4− ions to stable CuY2− ions. Based on the above, the solubility of copper phyllosilicate depends on the EDTA concentration, and the solution containing only Y4− ions makes it difficult to dissolve copper phyllosilicate. The dissolution of copper phyllosilicate caused by EDTA could be called as “dissolution effect”. 3.5 Catalytic evaluation Based on previous activity evaluation results [22], the ideal reaction temperature of 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst was 180 °C. The DMO hydrogenation catalytic performances of all catalysts are shown in Table 3 and Table S1. All the E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts have better conversion and selectivity than the Cu/SiO2 catalyst at 180 °C, and the E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst achieves comparable conversion and selectivity to the 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. The TOF value of E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (22.0) is higher than that of 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (16.0), and the TOF value of Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (14.3) is also higher than that of Cu/SiO2 catalyst (8.6). This shows that the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation can improve the catalytic performance of catalysts, and it could be further enhanced by introducing the appropriate amount of EDTA twice, that is, it is introduced at the same time as copper nitrate and reintroduced after ammonia evaporation. As can be seen from Fig. 8 , the E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst shows outstanding stability and catalytic performance during a long reaction period, the average conversion of DMO and the average selectivity of EG for the life evaluation of 300 h are 99.86 % and 97.58 %, respectively, while the maximum values are 99.99 % and 98.75 %. In addition, the stability of E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst also was evaluated under lower conversion. As shown in Fig. S4(I), it can be seen that the conversion of DMO is not less than 70 %, and the selectivity of EG is not less than 40 % during the evaluation process of 250 h at 170 °C, which shows that the catalyst can still maintain high stability even if under harsher conditions. As for the stability of Cu/SiO2, the earlier researches of our team have proved that it showed an obvious deactivation within 100 h [15,37], so it is not evaluated repeatedly. The activities of some copper-based catalysts in recent years also have been summarized in Table S5. It can be seen that the E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst can maintain higher activity and stability under more demanding conditions. 4 Discussion In our previous work, it was discovered that the 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst with an appropriate amount of EDTA introduced before the formation of copper phyllosilicate had a good catalytic performance. In this work, the effects of EDTA reintroduced after the formation of copper phyllosilicate on the formation of surface copper species and the structure–performance relationship of Cu/SiO2 catalysts are further investigated. It is worth mentioning that copper phyllosilicate has been formed after ammonia evaporation [26], in other words, the secondary introduction of EDTA also occurs after the formation of copper phyllosilicate. 4.1 Dissolution of copper phyllosilicate The results of BET show that the reintroduction of EDTA after the formation of copper phyllosilicate will result in the formation of larger pores. The dissolution experiment also proves that it will produce new SiO2 with the dissolution of copper phyllosilicate in the EDTA solution. The results of FT-IR show that the reintroduction of EDTA results in a significant decrease of copper phyllosilicate in E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts, and the decrease is more severe than that of Af-0.08-Cu/SiO2 catalyst which is introduced with EDTA only after ammonia evaporation. It shows that there is a “dissolution effect” as the EDTA is introduced after copper phyllosilicate formation. The dissolution experiment also indicates that copper phyllosilicate is more easily dissolved in an EDTA solution than in an EDTA salt solution. EDTA introduced along with copper nitrate has caused the formation of CuY2− ions in the solution, which inhibits the ionization of EDTA introduced after ammonia evaporation, so more unionized EDTA can be used to dissolve copper phyllosilicate. Therefore, the dissolution effect of twice introducing EDTA is more serious than that of introducing EDTA only after ammonia evaporation. 4.2 Redistribution of copper species The results of ICP show that the Cu loadings of catalysts do not decrease until the molar ratio of EDTA to Cu exceeds 0.04. The XPS results indicate that the moderate introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation does not cause a significant decrease in Cu+ species, and even slightly increases the Cu+ content. Based on the above, it can be inferred that new Cu(II) species will be formed at the same time with the dissolution of copper phyllosilicate. Chen et al. [11] thought in addition to copper phyllosilicate, the calcined catalyst prepared by the ammonia-evaporation method also contains ion-exchanged CuOSi units formed by the ion exchange of Cu2+ and SiO2 in the solution and CuO derived from copper hydroxide adsorbed in SiO2 layers. Importantly, CuOSi units could be reduced to form Cu2O, which is also the main source of Cu+. The dissolution experiment proves that the dissolution of copper phyllosilicate will produce new SiO2. Hence, it is believed that Cu2+ ions derived from dissolved copper phyllosilicate could form ion-exchanged CuOSi units with the newly formed SiO2. In addition, Cu2O from CuOSi units is more stable than Cu+ OSi unit from copper phyllosilicate, because the Cu+ OSi unit is easily oxidized back to copper phyllosilicate in the hydrogenation reaction [14]. Therefore, the amount of Cu+ species did not decrease with moderate EDTA when the total loading in the catalyst was almost constant. In contrast to the 0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the SCu of the E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts continuously decreases as more EDTA is introduced. This is owing to more Y4− ions generated from EDTA can chelate with copper ammonia ions to CuY2− ions, which causes a decrease in surface Cu species (like CuO). In this way, the amount of copper ammonia ions adsorbed in SiO2 accumulation layers by electrostatic interaction will decrease. Obviously, the amount of Cu0 derived from absorbed Cu2+ would decrease with the introduction of EDTA after ammonia evaporation, which is helpful to inhibit the size increase of Cu0 NPs due to agglomeration. Of course, too much Y4− in the solution will also seriously reduce the amount of surface Cu0 NPs. 4.3 Study on structure-activity relationship In this work, the EDTA introduced after ammonia evaporation can dissolve the copper phyllosilicate, causing Cu2+ ions to be released again, while those Cu2+ ions can form ion-exchanged CuOSi units with new SiO2 by ion exchange. It is important that the ion-exchanged CuOSi units could be reduced to new and stable Cu2O during pre-reduction. However, the dissolution effect of copper phyllosilicate will become serious with the excessive increase of EDTA, meanwhile, the pH value in the solution will also obviously decrease, which is not conducive to (but not completely terminated) the formation of ion-exchanged CuOSi units [38]. Therefore, the relative content of formed CuOSi units will be significantly less than that of dissolved copper phyllosilicate with the excessive introduction of EDTA, and then the XCu + will decrease significantly, such as E + 0.08-Cu/SiO2 catalyst. In short, the introduction of appropriate EDTA favors the formation of new Cu2O, and the reduction of Cu+ content is mainly due to the excessive dissolution of copper phyllosilicate and the decline of pH induced by excess EDTA. It is widely believed that the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0 is the key to catalytic hydrogenation for Cu/SiO2 catalysts. The higher TOF value reflects the stronger synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0. Ma et al. [29] believed that when the content of Cu0 species on the catalyst surface is insufficient (less than 20 m2/g), the hydrogenation performance is improved with the increase of the specific surface area of Cu0 species; when the Cu0 species on the catalyst surface is relatively sufficient, the Cu+ species play a leading role, and the hydrogenation performance is linearly positively correlated with the specific surface area of Cu+ species. Table 1 shows that the E + x-Cu/SiO2 catalysts have a similar Cu0 surface area, so the performances of catalysts are mainly determined by the Cu+ content, which is also proved by the consistent change trend of XCu + (Table 2) and TOF value (Table 3). As for Af-0.08-Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the lower TOF value is attributed to its lower SCu. Although the TOF value of E + 0.1-Cu/SiO2 is the lowest, its activity at 160 °C is still higher than that of Af-0.08-Cu/SiO2 catalyst, which may be due to the lower SBET and higher SCu resulting in agglomeration of Cu0. According to the particle size data derived from TEM and XRD (Table S3), the size of E + 0.1-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (DXRD = 6.5 nm and DTEM = 1.9 nm) is significantly higher than that of Af-0.08E-Cu/SiO2 catalyst (DXRD = 6.0 nm and DTEM = 1.7 nm), which is a good proof of our speculation. In conclusion, the appropriate EDTA introduced after ammonia evaporation promotes the formation of more and stable Cu+ sites, optimizes the number and dispersion of Cu0 species by the redistribution effect of copper species, which improves the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0. 5 Conclusions In this work, it is found that EDTA introduced after ammonia evaporation is able to dissolve part of copper phyllosilicate through the dissolution effect, then the release Cu2+ and silica because of dissolution could form ion-exchanged CuOSi units by ions exchange. The stable Cu2O formed by the reduction of new CuOSi units provides more stable Cu+ sites for the catalysts. EDTA also reduces the Cu2+ species adsorbed in the silica layers through chelation, thus promoting the formation of more dispersed small particle size Cu0NPs. The stable Cu+ sites and highly dispersed Cu0 sites improve the synergy of the two. The 99.86 % DMO conversion and 97.58 % EG selectivity can be obtained over the E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst at 180 °C during the life evaluation of 300 h. The late redistribution of copper species is successfully realized by introducing EDTA after ammonia evaporation, which improves the performance of the catalysts. It provides a novel scheme for the modification of copper-silicon catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The Cu/SiO2 catalyst is widely used in the catalytic hydrogenation reactions of numerous CO bonded compounds, due to its economy and efficiency. In this work, it is found that the EDTA introduced after ammonia evaporation could dissolve part of the copper phyllosilicate in the catalysts prepared by the ammonia-evaporation method, which is called the dissolution effect. Further research shows that the dissolution of the copper phyllosilicate will release Cu2+ ions and silica, then the two will take place ion exchange to form CuOSi units that could be reduced to stable Cu2O. To some extent, the formation of new Cu2O prevents the severe decrease of Cu+ caused by the dissolution of the copper phyllosilicate, which even makes E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst have the highest content of Cu+ (69.1 %). Moreover, the Cu2+ species adsorbed in the silica layers would decrease with the introduction of EDTA, which conduces to the formation of more dispersed Cu0 species with smaller particle sizes. In the hydrogenation reaction of dimethyl oxalate (DMO) to ethylene glycol (EG), the optimal catalytic performance (99.86 % DMO conversion and 97.58 % EG selectivity) can be obtained over the E + 0.02-Cu/SiO2 catalyst at 180 °C during the life evaluation of 300 h. This work reports a strategy for improving the performance and stability of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst by realizing the late redistribution of copper species.
coredata.dc:title: Late redistribution effect of copper species in the Cu/SiO2 catalyst induced by EDTA
